incident.name: Access to M; drive for Cathy Atkinson
incident.description: Beyer, Chris 2:52 PM (40 minutes ago) to me, Cathy, Michelle Chris, There is an "M" drive that Michelle uses to keep student medical records. Can we get access for Cathy Atkinson? She scans documents that come through fax for Michelle. It would simplify things significantly for us if she could save files directly to the M drive. Thanks!
incident.description_no_html: Beyer, Chris 2:52 PM (40 minutes ago) to me, Cathy, Michelle Chris, There is an "M" drive that Michelle uses to keep student medical records. Can we get access for Cathy Atkinson? She scans documents that come through fax for Michelle. It would simplify things significantly for us if she could save files directly to the M drive. Thanks!

incident.name: 3rd floor lab pc problems
incident.description: Student reported that a PC in the third floor lab had been frozen at the welcome screen for 3 days. I went up and restarted the computer (LIBRLAB300B-03), then attempted to log in using our Library student worker account. When logging in, it got to the desktop screen and then went black, not bringing anything on screen until I 3 finger saluted (CTRL-ALT-DELETE) to get the task manager. I then tried restarting and logging in with my own username and password, and got the same black screen phenomenon. While in the lab, I noticed that computers LIBRLAB300B-02 and 300B-07 were also experiencing the same problem. I didn't try all of the PCs, just those three.
incident.description_no_html: Student reported that a PC in the third floor lab had been frozen at the welcome screen for 3 days. I went up and restarted the computer (LIBRLAB300B-03), then attempted to log in using our Library student worker account. When logging in, it got to the desktop screen and then went black, not bringing anything on screen until I 3 finger saluted (CTRL-ALT-DELETE) to get the task manager. I then tried restarting and logging in with my own username and password, and got the same black screen phenomenon. While in the lab, I noticed that computers LIBRLAB300B-02 and 300B-07 were also experiencing the same problem. I didn't try all of the PCs, just those three.

incident.name: Resubscribe to Google Groups
incident.description: Hello, I have become unsubscribed from FirstYearGroup and SophomoreGroup and can no longer send mail to them. Kristina thought she had my FirstYearGroup subscription fixed yesterday, but it evidently didn't take. SophomoreGroup was working for me yesterday, but it is not working today.  Thanks, Chris Sanders-Ring
incident.description_no_html: Hello, I have become unsubscribed from FirstYearGroup and SophomoreGroup and can no longer send mail to them. Kristina thought she had my FirstYearGroup subscription fixed yesterday, but it evidently didn't take. SophomoreGroup was working for me yesterday, but it is not working today. Thanks, Chris Sanders-Ring

incident.name: Slate - Potential Security breach
incident.description_no_html: Research Alyson Meeks attempted login from Texas Slate Login Notification Dear Chris Vaughan, The user Alyson Meeks (alysonmeeks16) has attempted to login from an unrecognized location. The user account has been placed into a checkpoint status that requires a security administrator to release. User: Alyson Meeks (alysonmeeks16) Timestamp: 03/11/2019 at 09:28:10 AM Eastern Time Location: Houston, TX, United States Browser: Chrome Platform: Mac Network: Host1Plus IP: 191.101.170.17 UA: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_0) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/72.0.3626.121 Safari/537.36 DB: AGT If you believe this login to be unauthorized, you will want to disable the user's access and instruct the user to change their password. More information about login notifications and checkpoints is available in the Slate login notifications and checkpoints article.

incident.name: Slate - Potential Security breach
incident.description: Per Slate: Alexander Clark Thu, Mar 7, 1:01 PM (5 days ago) to me Dear Chris Vaughan, This is a precautionary email being sent to you as a designated Security Administrator at an organization using Slate. We would like to advise you of a potential risk to institutional single sign-on and password reset systems that has affected three colleges in the past week. First, Slate remains secure, and Slate has not been accessed without legitimate user credentials. Second, this is a precautionary email and does not indicate that your user accounts have been compromised in any way. We are sending this message out of an abundance of caution. We are aware of an unauthorized party that has used legitimate user credentials to gain access to Slate and other campus systems. This party has used the password reset systems of a college's single sign-on system to change the passwords of college staff. The single sign-on and password reset systems are hosted by the college, not by Technolutions/Slate. For example, a college might allow a user to reset their password by answering one or more security questions. These questions may be guessable, and some password reset systems may allow any number of attempts, or allow re-attempts after re-submitting a correct answer to a security question. The user would then be able to change the password and log in to campus systems using that authorized user account with the new password. One of the password reset systems, Avatier, used by at least one affected college, has or will be issuing a security hotfix to address this risk in their system. We strongly encourage all schools to review their password reset systems and protocols with their information security offices to ensure that there are sufficient controls in place to mitigate this risk. While we do not know your institution to be at risk at this time, given the nature of this recent activity, we believe that it is prudent for all institutions to review their security protocols. We also strongly encourage the use of two-factor authentication in your single sign-on systems. The Technolutions team is available to answer any questions and to help any institution update their single sign-on configuration if they desire to move to a system with two-factor authentication. If you have any questions, you may reply to this email message or submit a Service Desk request to the Security Risk group. Thank you for your time and attention to this important matter. Sincerest regards, Alexander Clark, Chief Executive Officer Peter Snow, Chief Information Officer Technolutions
incident.description_no_html: Per Slate: Alexander Clark Thu, Mar 7, 1:01 PM (5 days ago) to me Dear Chris Vaughan, This is a precautionary email being sent to you as a designated Security Administrator at an organization using Slate. We would like to advise you of a potential risk to institutional single sign-on and password reset systems that has affected three colleges in the past week. First, Slate remains secure, and Slate has not been accessed without legitimate user credentials. Second, this is a precautionary email and does not indicate that your user accounts have been compromised in any way. We are sending this message out of an abundance of caution. We are aware of an unauthorized party that has used legitimate user credentials to gain access to Slate and other campus systems. This party has used the password reset systems of a college's single sign-on system to change the passwords of college staff. The single sign-on and password reset systems are hosted by the college, not by Technolutions/Slate. For example, a college might allow a user to reset their password by answering one or more security questions. These questions may be guessable, and some password reset systems may allow any number of attempts, or allow re-attempts after re-submitting a correct answer to a security question. The user would then be able to change the password and log in to campus systems using that authorized user account with the new password. One of the password reset systems, Avatier, used by at least one affected college, has or will be issuing a security hotfix to address this risk in their system. We strongly encourage all schools to review their password reset systems and protocols with their information security offices to ensure that there are sufficient controls in place to mitigate this risk. While we do not know your institution to be at risk at this time, given the nature of this recent activity, we believe that it is prudent for all institutions to review their security protocols. We also strongly encourage the use of two-factor authentication in your single sign-on systems. The Technolutions team is available to answer any questions and to help any institution update their single sign-on configuration if they desire to move to a system with two-factor authentication. If you have any questions, you may reply to this email message or submit a Service Desk request to the Security Risk group. Thank you for your time and attention to this important matter. Sincerest regards, Alexander Clark, Chief Executive OfficerPeter Snow, Chief Information Officer Technolutions

incident.name: Roadtrip
incident.description: Our project-based programs use a blended learning format to foster authentic career exploration through interactive lessons and engaging multimedia content. Hi Chris and Tammy, I am reaching out because I was told you were the first step in the process of getting a new product in Career Development. We are working on a contract with a company called Road Trip Nation (https://roadtripnation.com/), contract attached. I am not sure how much your office needs to do with this one, as it is similar to Goin Global, which we just purchased. Talking with my contact at the organization, they use a Manual Code to allow our students to create an account on their website, which we will provide access to on Handshake. I will be sending this contract over to Sheri Curan as well. Please let me know if you have any questions or need any additional information. I have not done this process before, so not sure what you would need from me. Thanks!

incident.name: Access Database Is Pausing
incident.description: Our Access database, Q:\Education\Ed Students.accdb, has been pausing a few times per day for almost a week. Julie Oliger and I are the only ones who use it, and we are both experiencing this problem whether we are both in it or when only one of us is. These "pauses" happen even if we aren't running anything. They last 5-20 seconds each. If we click on something when a "pause" is happening we have to close out and come back in. This is different from "Not Responding." The indicator that a "pause" is happening is a blank 2" band at the top of the application.
incident.description_no_html: Our Access database, Q:\Education\Ed Students.accdb, has been pausing a few times per day for almost a week. Julie Oliger and I are the only ones who use it, and we are both experiencing this problem whether we are both in it or when only one of us is. These "pauses" happen even if we aren't running anything. They last 5-20 seconds each. If we click on something when a "pause" is happening we have to close out and come back in. This is different from "Not Responding." The indicator that a "pause" is happening is a blank 2" band at the top of the application.

incident.name: Clock incorrect for 45 minutes after restart
incident.description: Sarah called about the clock being wrong when she started up her computer every day. When she called at 9:00, it hadn't synced up for at least 45 minutes. It said the time was about 9:50. By the time we got off of the phone, it had synced up.

incident.name: Program the message button on Kathy's voicemail
incident.description: Karen called about Kathy's voicemail button. She is unable to use the button to check her voicemails. We need to get it programmed to sign in directly. ----- In the meantime, here are the directions to sign into voicemail without a programmed button: From a campus phone, dial 7700 (from an off-campus phone, dial 309-794-7700) Dial your extension Dial 77 + your extension (or the password that you have changed)
incident.description_no_html: Karen called about Kathy's voicemail button. She is unable to use the button to check her voicemails. We need to get it programmed to sign in directly. ----- In the meantime, here are the directions to sign into voicemail without a programmed button: From a campus phone, dial 7700 (from an off-campus phone, dial 309-794-7700) Dial your extension Dial 77 + your extension (or the password that you have changed)
